div.head: THE LADIES CHAMPION.
div.p:
OH! for a leg, an arm, or a limb of that Devil incarnate, the woman-hater, and Enemy to multiplication, the Author of the Wandering whore. Come Sirrah, look to your hits, I have a whole bundle of rods in pi≈øs for thee, quod de≈øertur non aufertur, thy puni≈øhment's onely deferr'd for a while, thou ≈øhalt have thy ≈øwing, and thou know≈øt what followes after; for I know thou'lt run thy ≈øelf out of breath ≈øhortly: All thy Pumpings, Inventions, Romances, Stories of the Strummulo, the Merkin, Spunges of ≈øeveral ≈øorts, Scotch-≈øpur, Padlocks, with the Li≈øt of Crafty bauds, Common whores, Wanderers, Pimps and Trappanners, ≈øhall not prevent it; Thou did≈øt fir≈øt begin with private whores, Cuckolds, and Cuckold-makers under the notion and name of Mercurius Philalethes, but that Element was too hot to hold, come this will be out of the frying pan into the fire; thou know≈øt Mrs. B‚Äî in C‚Äî would have given ten pounds for thy di≈øcovery and apprehen≈øion, Mrs. S‚Äî will ≈øpend fifty pounds to vindicate her cau≈øe, & make thee exemplary, and yet thou dar≈øt enter the Li≈øt again≈øt a thou≈øand; beware their Clutches, le≈øt they ≈øouce thee in Thetis poudering tub to make meat for Sharks and Shaddocks, or fright thee like poor Lazari ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ o, by shaving thee, to≈ø≈øing thee in a blanket naked, and turning the out of
thy ≈øeven ≈øen≈øes, whil≈øt they cry Hey for the brave women-barbers in Drury-lane, they'l ≈øpoyl thy occupation for inveighing again≈øt their's, off goes thy ≈øtones as ≈øure as a gun or a club to make Billjard balls on, and thy yard their Billjard-≈øtick to play at their Portalls, then ≈øay thy Pater-no≈øter, ≈øpeak with all thy friends, for they'r re≈øolv'd (if they catch thee once) to ≈øee whether there be any worms in thy brains; and if ≈øo, to wa≈øh them out, and put thy brains in again, and if that wont ≈øerve thy turn, half an hour's exerci≈øe of their preparation will be wor≈øe then the pox or purgatory; Come Bits and Bacon, thou know≈øt how Thom.E.‚Äîwas u≈øed for thy ≈øake in Holborn, kickt up and down like a football, and forc't to fly for fear of leaving of his brans behinde him, or among≈øt them: was not Dick L‚Äîarre≈øted (and forc't to pawn his ≈øhirt and his cloak to pay his fees) by Merrick? And was not another arre≈øted by Farmer the Poulterer in Newgate-market upon ≈øuppo≈øition of being the Author of the Wandring whore? 'tis true his innocency cleered him to the dammage of Su. Lemings pitiful Poulterer, who fea≈øted him and his friends carca≈øes by way of Compo≈øition with a Capon, Teals, Goo≈øe, Wine, &c. to the value of forty ≈øhillings, and upwards, making him pay for his mi≈øtake and ignorance: Thou De≈øperado, if Glover, Player, or Thom-Stern light on thee han≈øomly, ≈øay well fair a light pair of heels, they'l try whether thou art a kin to an Iri≈øh man or no, and teach thee Hey then up go we, up tayls all, the Pitchers gone to'th wall. But hear ‚Ä¢ you ≈øirrah, is whore a common name to all women, which is ≈øo common with thee? thou ≈øay'≈øt foul Devil, thou ha≈øt a Li≈øt of fifteen hundred Caterpillars and poy≈øonous vermine
which want de≈øtroying, beware le≈øt a le≈ø≈øer number don't devour thee, or burn thee in ≈øome Capacious C‚Äî or other, or quarter thee in pieces among≈øt them, ≈øending thy bones and fle≈øh among≈øt the Crew, in order to the burning thereof, with as much Ceremony as Peter Aretine for inventing the ≈øix and thirty ≈øeveral ways and po≈øtures of occupying, or for being an Heretick; But Sirrah would not a whore be a nece≈ø≈øary evil (as is u≈øually ≈øaid of all women kind) if thou had≈øt not the gift of continence? prithee what cau≈øe or provi≈øion is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, mo≈øt lawful, lea≈øt offen≈øive, and lea≈øt charges? ought we not among≈øt all evils to chu≈øe the lea≈øt? When then, ≈øirrah, is not u≈øing a hand≈øom Girl whol≈øome, plea≈øurable, and tollerable? For ≈øince the number of females do far exceed that of males, doubtle≈øs they would have a little of that ≈øame as well as the re≈øt of their fellow Creatures, who are all fle≈øh and blood, and que≈øtionle≈øs were not brought into the world with ≈øuch in≈øtruments for no purpo≈øe or profit: ≈øo that I conceive (in behalf of Ladies and Madams in our order) it le≈øs criminal for a man to go and lie with a wench (I will not ≈øay with another mans wife) then to lie with his wife when ≈øhe is big with Childe, or during her lying in Childe-bed, in this Ca≈øe what cour≈øe or remedy ≈øhall a man take and u≈øe, who has not this Gift of Continence, and may neither lie with his own wife, nor his neighbors wife, nor his mayd, his nur≈øe, nor with a whore? que≈øtionle≈øs there is a lawful provi≈øion made in this Ca≈øe of Extremity, which I judge, conceive and conclude to be in Polygamy, that is, in having plurality, ≈øeveral, or many wives at one and the ≈øame time together, as the be≈øt Expedient for generation
and Continency, and ≈øtricte≈øt way to have few or no whores at all, as it is at this day among≈øt the Turks, where one man may have as many wives as he plea≈øes, ≈øo he can maintain them and their children, or if they do maintain their husbands. Put the Ca≈øe an Heyr of a va≈øt and yeerly revenue, to who≈øe i≈ø≈øue this E≈øtate is entayld, ≈øhould marry, or be compell'd for lucre of mony to bed with a per≈øon he loves not, or one that proves barren, this weathly per≈øon is de≈øirous of Children to whom he would leave his E≈øtate, or el≈øe he loo≈øes it, leaving to it ≈øtrangers which never got it, would not this mans marriage to a fruitful vvife be matter of much rejoycing to him, and to every hone≈øt and cha≈øt vvife, if it vvere their condition, to ≈øee the fruits of their labours? a Pre≈øident vvhereof I remember to be verified of an Ea≈øt-India Merchant (of ≈øomewhat a different quality) who was exceeding de≈øirous to have his wife got with childe, a thing he could not perform him≈øelf,) giving her free leave ≈øo to do during his ab≈øence, provided it were done with a Gentleman; not long after a Knights ≈øon coming to her hou≈øe, brought a bill of Exchange for a con≈øiderable ≈øum of moneys, which accordingly was accepted, and the day of payment appointed; the plea≈øant Gentlewomen made very much of him, and agreed that the ≈øame day he received his mony, he ≈øhould lie with her all night till the morrow; which was accordingly done, ≈øhe got with childe of a boy, and in ten months following born, and put forth to nur≈øe at Bednal Green, (where wanted no Expences or attendance) without ≈øu≈øpicion or jealou≈øy of the father, in regard of the ≈øuddain di≈øpatch thereof after her husband departure, not long after her husband
arriv'd at home ≈øafely, who ≈øeeing no appearance of his la≈øt ≈øcuffle with his wife, lamented the want of i≈ø≈øue, chyding her for not making u≈øe of that freedom he had allowed her during his ab≈øence, which cau≈øed her to admire his humor, and relate her fore-pa≈ø≈øed action, ≈øaying there was a brave boy begot by a brave fellow, a Knights ≈øon, and put out to nur≈øe in ≈øuch a place, and of ≈øuch an age; the newes whereof made him impatient of ≈øeeing him, which he did the day following early; where after plentiful gifts to the nur≈øe, hugging, ki≈ø≈øing and embracing of the childe, he told her he came to fetch away the childe, to which ≈øhe ≈øaid, it could not be di≈øpen≈ø'd with, without the knowledge of the per≈øon who delivered him to her, and paid for his keeping, on which he went away di≈øcontented to the Knights ≈øon, telling him he would ≈øpend 300 l. but he would have him; the other an≈øwered he vvould ≈øpend 500 l. but he vvould keep him, ≈øo that incontinently a Sute vvas commenced, at va≈øt charges on both ≈øides, ere the verdict came to be given up, vvhich vvas likely to go again≈øt the Merchant; of vvhom one Noy the Prothonotory ≈øaid, demanding his fee, he vvould turn the ≈øcales, vvhich accordingly fell out, and ≈øpeaking to the Judge and the Bench, de≈øired the favor to ≈øpeak one or tvvo vvords more to the matter, vvhich in regard of the variety of pleadings, and multiplicity of Lavvyers there pre≈øent, vvas thought ≈øuperfluous, and needle≈øs, yet granted by the Judge, to vvhom he ≈øpake, My Lord, put the ca≈øe that your Honor and I have each of us a piece of ground adjoyning to each other, and nothing but a fence or a ditch betvvixt them, you keep a bull in one part, and I keep Covves on the other, your bull break
in among≈øt my Cowes, and gets them with Calves, does not the≈øe calves belong to the owner of the Cowes? whereupon the verdict was given on the Merchants ≈øide: who brought him up to the Univer≈øity, and dying left his whole E≈øtate to him, the Knights ≈øon continu'd unmarried to his dying day, (having known her but that once) left his whole E≈øtate likewi≈øe to him: here's a rich Pre≈øident for all barren women, all women big with Childe, and all old women to follow, in≈øtead of being jealous of their husbands, 'tis an excellent way to creace love in≈øtead of hatred among≈øt them, if they had but a right under≈øtanding of each other, to let their husbands with free con≈øent take another wife by whom he may have children; for what were it for the Elder to be nur≈øe to the yonger wife, to have the favor and ≈ømiles of her husband, e≈øpecially where there is di≈øparity of yeers, of di≈ø≈øimilitude in conditions; I que≈øtion whether the ≈øowing ≈øuch precious ≈øeed in a barren ≈øoyl is an≈øwerable, fitting, or different from ≈øowing it among≈øt whores, and if ≈øo, the marriage of another prevents it, proving fruitful, and the peru≈øal of Ochinu ‚Ä¢ Dialogues of Polygamy and Divorce, will convince any rational ≈øoul of the truth hereof, publi≈øhed and printed for J‚ÄîG‚Äîonce living in Cornhil. And now have at the new fa≈øhion'd Dialogues written ≈øometimes by a Convert, ≈øometimes by a Conver≈øant, and another time by Eubulus, and next time by I cannot tell whom or what, and yet all one and the ≈øame hand again: I tell thee the≈øe poor Creatures term'd whores will ≈øerve to ≈øupply a mans wants better then marrying a wench, having nothing to ≈øhow for't but two pair of legs in one pair of ≈øheets, with a windmil and watermil, from whence
comes no gri≈øt vendible: again, a wife a man cannot put off as one may a whore with eighteen pence or a couple of boards without any di≈øturbance or greater prejudice, if he ≈øcape pockyfying: again, if a man in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe meddle with a maid, he mu≈øt be forc'd either to marry her or maintain her and her childe, which is not ≈øo with a whore, who ≈øeldom receives any wages after her work is over, but before hand, and that ≈øo frequently that they ≈øeldom prove with Childe, as Peg Cro≈øs the ≈øhort A‚ÄîWanderer is, as thou term≈øt her, thou pretende≈øt to be their profe≈ø≈ø't enemy both in Principles and Practi≈øes, whence comes ≈øuch frigidity, and coldne≈øs, art thou not one of the Decayed Occupiers thou talk'≈øt of ‚Ä¢ 'tis likely ≈øo, or el≈øe ha≈øt lo≈øt thy Evidence, or been ≈øerv'd as they do Eunuchs in other Countryes, where their ≈øtones are cut out, who would otherwi≈øe prove the ≈øtoute≈øt ≈øtallions, as an approved and experienc'd Doctor ob≈øerv'd of one among≈øt them who would lie tickling and towzing of his Mi≈øtri≈øs with his ≈øtanding T‚Äîfor three or four hours, nay all night ≈øometimes together, without tyring, but with no Ejection, it being impo≈ø≈øible: but I believe thou would≈øt have them go to't with Carrets and Par≈ønips, as the milk-maids did with one another till they let them ≈ølip over head and ears, for want of tying a ≈øtring about them irrecoverably, and the ≈øpoyling of a good commodity, or moul for ca≈øting boyes and girles in: what would have become of that late and yong lady, in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, of whom I ≈øhall relate a plea≈øing ≈øtory, from whom ≈øprung ≈øeveral curious branches, who≈øe father was, and is a per≈øon of great wealth and riches, yet covetous, and willing to rid his hands of her, at as ea≈øy a rate as he could to another
of a va≈øt E≈øtate likewi≈øe, but could not bring his de≈øigns to perfection upon him, for upon the tender of a thou≈øand pounds, he would not ≈øeem to accept her without the addition of five hundred more, whereupon without the privity of his Father, Mother, or any other, but him≈øelf, his Mi≈øtri≈øs, and the Steward, this plot was contrived and executed, vvhich vvas to marry her, get her vvith childe, come novv and then to her in privacy, leaving her vvith her Parents, till the je≈øt broke forth, vvhich in fevv months follovving did ≈øo, vvho≈øe mother de≈øcrying the ri≈øing of her belly, que≈øtioned her daughter about the premi≈øes, to vvhom ≈øhe an≈øvvered, that ≈øuch a per≈øon, not guilty thereof, had done it; vvhich exceedingly troubled her, vvhich cau≈øed her to reveal it to her husband, vvho re≈øented it vvith much more horror, for the di≈øhonor vvould fall upon him, and his vvhole family: in this tryal his vvits vvere put to't, concealing it from all others, till his ≈øtevvard vvho vvas deep in the plot, gave him an inckling thereof, of vvhom he ask't councel, vvho an≈øvvered him, there vvas no vvay under heaven but to marry her to her former ≈øuitor, vvhich he vvell liked of, and accordingly he and his ≈øtevvard rode to vi≈øit him, vvhere they vvere exceeding vvelcom, in≈øomuch that the old man invites him by way of retribution and retaliation to his hou≈øe, which he forthwith accepted: riding together the matter was ≈øtarted, and renewed betwixt him and his daughter, which the old man gladly received, telling him he ≈øhould have the 1500 l. but he would have writings drawn betwixt each other, before the ≈øight of his daughter; which being completed, the daughter was ≈øent for, who appeared big-bellyed, whereat with a
counterfeit amazedne≈øs, he ≈øaid, How now Peg; what have you done? and to the father, I'le have none of your daughter, to which the old man replyed, taking him by the ≈øleeve, Son, ≈øon, a bargain's a bargain: I tell you Sir, quoth the Gentleman, except you double the portion for the di≈øhonor done me, I will not have your daughter. Come, come Sir, I tell yee a bargain's a bargain, to avoid all trouble you ≈øhall have your portion doubled, which was accordingly performed ere the plot was di≈øcovered. Now face about to the right, I'le charge thee agen and agen, for I have but been skirmi≈øhing and bickering all this while, have at thee, with thunder and lightning, I'le come Pell-mell upon thee: Is thy name Eubulus with a hor≈øe-pox to thee, thou think≈øt to put the cramp in my mouth with a hard word, I warrant thee, but I'le anatomize thy meaning, 'tis a good Councellor by the figure Ironia e contrario, let thee alone in thy roguery, and thou'lt teach us all the plain way to occupying: for all thy pretended ≈øanctity, doubtle≈øs thou art a yong ≈øaint, but an old devil from experience, and the Devil is ≈øeemingly the be≈øt Doctor: Will thy councel gain the Ely≈øian fields, ≈øatisfy Charon the ferry-man of Hell, or lead the ≈øafe way to Bli≈øs? I have taught thee in my method to Ro≈øy-Crucian Phy≈øick, borrow'd of that learned and ingenious Writer Mr. A≈øhmole: no, there's no ≈øuch thing in nature, I would have ≈øaid, rerum natura, but for frighting my Ladies, and puzzling thy empty pate, thou think≈øt all thy pack-thread intelligence mu≈øt all pa≈øs for verities, but I that am Eugenius Theodidactus of my own creating, and Secretary to Naturals, ≈øay, Cujus contrarium verum e≈øt, con≈øtrue me that if thou can≈øt Enbulus;
for I'le have thee to know, I under≈øtand Hebrew, Arabick and Syriack as much as the Grand Sultan does Welch and Engli≈øh Well, but thy name and thy nature are not all one, ≈øirrah, I'de have thee to know I am a learned A≈øinus, ex quovis ligno uon fit mercurius; the Devils in thee for under≈øtanding, if thou know≈øt that too: for I believe thou wert never at the Uni Afity of Padua, where I acted the part of Ignoramus in≈øtead of Commencing, yet I'le give my de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nition according to my degrees of Eubulus; Eubulus when I acted Acola≈øtes the prodigal, was my good Councellor again≈øt wenching; Eubulus, was my right-hand-Councellor again≈øt High-way-men, Pick-pockets, and Para≈øites. Eubulus was always again≈øt ≈øhaking of Elbows, Tables, Cards, and Gamings, and other cheating (as that of Sir‚ÄîMoreland, of 40 pieces of gold in a dream,) and making the world believe my brains lay in a Long-lane Plu≈øh-jacket, a Green-bag, a reverend-≈øtaff, and telling of fortunes, or rayling at hone≈øt Fumigo≈øus my old enemy, for not flattering me in my ignorance. Eubulus was my friend after I had eaten the husks of beanes and pea≈øe among≈øt the hogs, but I never ≈øaw any calf but my ≈øelf: but this is a damnable Excur≈øion, if I ≈øhould weary the patience of my Ladies of plea≈øure, to whom I commend the reading of my Advice to a Daughter ≈øtoln out of Felthams Re≈øolves, Modern Policyes, Overburyes Characters, &c. taking the other bout with Eubulus, and then farewel: Ide have thee to know I ≈øcorn to take ≈øuch a puppyes councel, for I have found more profit by pinching and cheating, then thou ≈øhalt ever do by writing or ≈øpeaking go teach thy dogs to dance: but I ≈øhall not leave thee
≈øo neither, wa'≈øt not an impudent part of thee, to di≈øcover who were Cuckolds and who were Cuckold-makers, of both ≈øexes: thou baudy Author, and abu≈øive Raskal, is it convenient to ≈øpeak truth at all times, no not to Quaery it? Whether Old Actaeon was ever coop't up like a Guinny Big? whether Actaeons picture were more proper then a Black Boy? whether the ≈øeven Stars in L.‚Äîmight not more properly be the ≈øeven deadly ≈øins? Whether the ≈øign of the Devil were not more ≈øutable for the Angel in W‚Äîwhether ever a Ba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er in London look't like Ma≈øsienello of Naples? Whether Smacket upon a wenches bum-trinket is not a term of art for every Barbers mouth? and Have you any wood to cleave, a profitable ≈øentence on Hor≈øledown? Whether Su Leming? A‚Äîdoes not make buttons with the ≈øtrings of her fiddle, ever ≈øince the di≈øcovery of Ben. R‚Äîhis drawing a tabby gown out of his Codpiece? Whether old father Fiery-facias will ever be cur'd of his red no≈øe, till he leaves looking under the Lines of Communication? Whether old Rats will ever leave loving of Chee≈øe? Whether that which is bred in the bone, will ever out of the fle≈øh? Whether a Flaunders Mare or a beautiful wench naked is the better bed-fellow? Whether plain-horns or gilt-horns are mo≈øt fa≈øhionable? Whether the Butchers brindle does not want Hukins his Quidlibets? Whether London vvill ever be vvithout Cuckolds and Cuckoldmakers? Whether the French mans riding on the no≈øe, does not ≈øpoyl a good occupation? Whether it be mo≈øt lavvful to lie vvith a mans maid, his nur≈øe, or his ovvn wife, in Gander-mouth? Whether any man can cure the Cut of his finger by thru≈øting it up a C‚Äîas I‚Äîdid? Whether
lying with a feeble husband, or a ≈øtouti≈øtallion, cures a womans melancholy? Whether Midwifes get mo≈øt by mens or womens tayls?
